DeregistrationReasonOtherText: removed all the anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The overall approach to accidental release prevention and emergency response is to inform all interested persons including employees, neighbors, and agencies that Caulkins Indiantown Citrus is complying with all applicable local, state and federal regulations dealing with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and usage of hazardous chemicals.  In this way we promote overall plant, worker, and public safety.  These programs enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of toxic substances.  Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.
Our safety programs are applied to any activity involving hazardous chemicals including any use, storage, handling, or the on-site movement of such chemicals, or combination of these activities.  
Our safety program prevents accidents because it focuses on the rules, procedures, training, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and are improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at this facility.

Regulated substances utilized at Caulkins Indiantown Citrus covered under this regulation include the following:             1.  Anhydrous Ammonia
                             2.  Peracetic Acid

Worst-case scenario:
The worst-case scenario would be a failure of the high pressure receiver containing 17600 pounds of anhydrous ammonia releasing its entire contents over a 10 minute period.  Using the EPA accepted method (RMP Comp) for determining the distance ammonia could travel before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public would be 1.6 miles.
This scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:  industry standards for the manufacture and quality control of pressure vessels;  ammonia is not corrosive in this service; pressure safety valves limit operating pressure in the vessels; the a

ccident prevention program in place at this facility which includes the mechanical integrity program for regular maintenance, daily inspections, testing and replacement of equipment as necessary; utilization of the emergency response plans, and the use of a qualified outside source to provide monthly audits of Caulkins Indiantown Citrus refrigeration system(s). 

Five Year Accident History:
Caulkins Indiantown Citrus Company has not had any releases of anhydrous ammonia during the past five years.

Emergency Response Program: 
The emergency response program at Caulkins Indiantown Citrus involves all employees.  Training is conducted in accordance with OSHA and industry standards.  Annual drills are conducted using both company and non-company personnel to ensure timely and accurate responses should an accidental release occur.
